entry.title: Re: SAP AVC OBJECT DEPENDENCY
entry.content:
Hello Ankit,

The syntax error occurs because the editor syntax in AVC differs from that of other programming languages, such as ABAP. You can refer to this link for our documentation on procedure syntax (it works the same way in Public and Private Cloud/On Premise). 

As in the example in the documentation, the 'THEN' part of the IF statement goes first (but without the keyword THEN), and the IF part follows (without an ENDIF):

$SELF.ALTO_TEST = ($PARENT.ALTO - 0.30) * 2 IF $PARENT.COLOR_COMPONENTES = 'GRIS'.

Please check if this resolves the issue, or if you still encounter a syntax error.

Best Regards,

Florian

entry.title: Re: How to find out which CDS Views are used in a Fiori A...
entry.content:
Good day @Orhan_Salman 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

To summarise, in public cloud you cannot view CDS view definitions directly in the backend but SAP provides official tools to trace them whilst adhering to the clean core approach in public cloud. You can use the App Support tool in the Fiori app to find its OData service. Look up that service in the Fiori Lab or SAP API Business Hub. These list the CDS views and entities used. Optionally, check Custom Fields and Logic for released CDS views in that business area. For example, Manage Sales Orders uses th OData service API_SALES_ORDER_SRV. This is built on the CDS view I_SalesOrder and its consumption view C_SalesOrderWthFldSel.

Below is a detailed option you can consider:

Open the Manage Sales Order app

Click the User Menu --> More --> App Support.

In the App Support pop-up, go to App information Ã  Technical Information. You will see all available details. This provides an SAP-official trace from Fiori app.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: From Hype to Hands-On: Level Up Your AI Skills This November
entry.content:
In the age of AI, the skills we build today will define how we work tomorrow. Thatâ€™s why weâ€™ve launched a monthly series of blogs that spotlight the latest AI learning assets and upcoming learning opportunities.

Building on my previous blog where I introduced you to our newest AI live sessions Beyond Hype (which is all about getting productive with SAP Business AI), let me follow up with you on your most asked questions:

  1. What is Embedded AI?
    This is where SAP embeds AI features directly into its cloud solutions across the Business Suite, such as SAP SuccessFactors or SAP Customer Experience. In other words, these AI capabilities operate natively inside core business applications such as ERP, procurement, HR, and supply chain management. SAP customers benefit from AI immediately with out-of-the-box AI features which minimizes the need to build custom solutions from scratch. 

    Do you know about the Embedded AI Explained page that not only provides examples of embedded AI capabilities in enterprise solutions but also includes other helpful information? No? Check it out! My favorite embedded AI feature is SAP SuccessFactors Performance and Goals performance goal creation and development goal creation: Thanks to AI these features reduce the time needed to ideate and draft goal content while also making goals more concise. This slide deck showcases other ways in which SAP Business AI capabilities create value for every aspect of your business through key personas.

  2. Is there a place to get a complete overview of available AI features and Joule agents?
    Of course there is! Do you know you can explore AI offerings in the AI Catalog? It currently shows 313 AI Agents and Features, spanning from Beta, Early Adopter Care, and generally available. Just click on a feature to see further resources, roadmap info, and pricing details.


  3. Is there a step-by-step activation guide to set up Joule?
    Weâ€™ve got you! SAP Content Discovery provides a library of missions to get started with SAP Business AI. Missions include best practices and step-by-step guidance for use case implementation, supported by mission experts and the SAP Community. Start the Discovery Center Mission to establish a unified Joule instance and explore setup guides that include Joule in . Once you have Joule up and running, watch this video to see scenarios where Joule can significantly enhance employee productivity and check out the prompt cheat sheets in the Get Started with Joule deck.

     

    You also asked what the difference is between Joule and SAP Joule for Consultants. While both offer and share the same conversational user experience, they do actually address different needs and user groups. With Joule, business users can use natural language requests to receive conversational help when navigating their SAP systems, automating business transactions, getting insights grounded in their business data, and also when accelerating complex multi-step workflows with AI agents. SAP Joule for Consultants is more aligned with assisting system integrators and internal consultants who are delivering SAP projects and cloud transformations. With SAP Joule for Consultants, consultants get the expert-level guidance they need on-demand to help them make better decisions and execute project tasks according to best practices.

Want to dive deeper into the content? Rewatch the sessions and access the session material via SAP Learning Hub (subscription required):

  • Embedded AI in Action: Top Use Cases You Can Activate Today (recording)
  • From Activation to Application: Getting Started with SAP Joule for Consultants (recording)

Speaking of SAP Joule for Consultants: Have you heard about the SAP Mission to enable SAP Joule for Consultants? As you can see, the setup process is straightforward and the prerequisites for using it include a BTP Global Account, Cloud Identity Services, Access to EU10 or EU11, SAP AI Units (8019164).

Once youâ€™ve enabled SAP Joule for Consultants, youâ€™ll want to find out how to get started. For this, take a look at the video to tour the product and discover best practices. If you want to understand the business value and explore key capabilities and differentiators, complete the Learning Journey â€œAccelerating SAP Project Delivery Using SAP Joule for Consultantsâ€.

 

Hi Joule, where should I get started with the latest learning resources? *

Apart from live enablement sessions, explore our latest on-demand learning resources:

  • If you missed Devtoberfest by SAP TechEd, make sure to watch the recordings. Highlights include:
    • Manage and Optimize Prompts in SAP AI Core: Concepts and application (recording)
    • Demystifying the MCP, A2A, and ACP Protocols to Build Custom Multi-Agent Systems (recording)
    • Boost Your Developer Satisfaction with SAP Joule for Developers, ABAP AI Capabilities (recording)

* Powered by the machine learning technology of SAP AI Business Services, personalized recommendations are generated to employees, in one place on the Learning home page, based on employee data.

As we look ahead into November, weâ€™re excited to share with you a new lineup of learning opportunities designed to help you expand your knowledge and make AI an advantage in your role:

  • November, 11, 3 pm CET: Build Your Own AI Solution with Generative AI hub. Understand the exact steps to build, extend, and run custom AI solutions.
  • November, 13, 4 pm CET: All Things Business AI: Latest Insights, Updates & Live Demos. Learn how to apply AI to streamline processes, boost performance, and unlock new value across your enterprise.

Stay tuned for more, and happy learning! ğŸš€

Joule #Joule agents AI Foundation Joule Studio #SAP Joule for Consultants SAP Business AI #AI Enablement #AI Skills

entry.title: SAP TechEd on Tour Bangalore: Ignite innovation and expand your SAP network in the APAC region
entry.content:
Join us for SAP TechEd on Tour Bangalore, a leading event â€“ now for the first time in Bangalore â€“ tailored for developers, engineers, and technologists from global enterprises and partner ecosystems, taking place on November 25-26, 2025. If you're passionate about SAP technologies like SAP Business Suite, generative AI, SAP Build, or Joule, and are eager to turn your ideas into innovation with the support of a global community of peers and experts, then this is the event for you. Attendees will gain access to hands-on workshops, immersive demos, and direct engagement with SAP specialists to explore how these innovations can transform their business (session catalog).

Register today to secure your spot and be part of this transformative experience!

Why attend SAP TechEd on Tour Bangalore?

  • Unlock SAPâ€™s latest innovations: One of the highlights is the exploration of AI innovations and discovering the future of business intelligence, SAP Business Suite on SAP Business Technology Platform and SAP Business Data Cloud, and AI-driven solutions. The event is your gateway to understanding how AI can revolutionize your enterprise landscape.
  • Participate in hands-on workshops and certification bootcamps: SAP TechEd on Tour Bangalore offers a wide array of topics designed to broaden your technical expertise, validate your skills and to immerse yourself in scenarios that replicate everyday challenges. Nine talk tracks offer key topics highly relevant for SAP MaxAttention customers such as automation, business transformation management, cloud lifecycle management, digital transformation with cloud ERP, and innovations on the SAP Business Technology Platform. Take the opportunity to complete an SAP Certification exam on site for free (SAP Generative AI Developer or SAP Build Developer).
  • Expand your community, connect and collaborate: Engage with a network of developers in Community Talks to hear firsthand how organizations are addressing real-world business and IT challenges using SAPâ€™s latest technologies. Let conversation spark innovation by joining a global community of experts from the region.

At SAP TechEd on Tour Bangalore, you can hear more about the evolution of SAP MaxAttention, so join us at our SAP MaxAttention booth or sign up for Sebastien Denesâ€™ (Head of Global Premium Engagements Xperience) session.

Welcome to SAP TechEd on Tour Bangalore!

entry.title: SAP Fiori: Adding Field Validation Based on Other Field Values Using Controller Extensions OData V2
entry.content:
In many project use cases, we often encounter situations where the validity of one field depends on the value of another. For example, when a flag is updated or a key date is modified, the user must provide additional comments before saving the record.


In this blog post, Iâ€™ll walk you through how I implemented such conditional validations in a Fiori Elements Object Page using Controller Extensions.

Scenario

I had a requirement where:

  1. If the Last Working Date (LWD) was changed, then the Additional Comments (ARD Comments) field must not be empty.

  2. If certain flags or dropdown values were set to specific conditions (like â€œYâ€ or a specific code), corresponding comment fields were required before allowing the user to save.

Instead of modifying the generated metadata or annotations, I handled these validations using the Controller Extensionâ€™s beforeSaveExtension hook, which is triggered before the save action.

Implementation

1. Adding controller extension :- Add the controller extension file in app/webapp/ext/controller as  ObjectPageExt.controller.js

2. Add the controller file in manifest.json

"sap.ui5": {
    "flexEnabled": true,
    // other fields
    "resources": {
      "css": []
    },
    "routing": {
      "config": {},
      "routes": [],
      "targets": {}
    },
    "extends": {
      "extensions": {
        "sap.ui.controllerExtensions": {
          "sap.suite.ui.generic.template.ObjectPage.view.Details": {
            "controllerName": "app.ext.controller.ObjectPageExt"
          }
        }
      }
    }
  },

3. ObjectPageExt.controller.js

sap.ui.define(["sap/ui/core/mvc/ControllerExtension", "sap/m/MessageBox"], function (ControllerExtension, MessageBox) {
    "use strict";

    return ControllerExtension.extend("offboardingdashboard.ext.controller.ObjectPageExt", {
        override: {
            beforeSaveExtension: function () {
                const oContext = this.getView().getBindingContext();
                if (!oContext) return Promise.resolve();

                const oModel = oContext.getModel();
                const sPath = oContext.getPath();
                const oNewData = oContext.getObject(); // Current draft data

                // --- Step 1: Get the original (active) entity data ---
                const oOriginalData = oModel.getOriginalProperty
                    ? oModel.getOriginalProperty(sPath)
                    : null;

                // --- Step 2: Detect change in Last Working Date ---
                let bLwdChanged = false;
                if (oOriginalData && oOriginalData.cust_lastworkingdate && oNewData.cust_lastworkingdate) {
                    const dNew = new Date(oNewData.cust_lastworkingdate);
                    const dOld = new Date(oOriginalData.cust_lastworkingdate);
                    bLwdChanged = dNew.getTime() !== dOld.getTime();
                } else if (oOriginalData && oOriginalData.cust_lastworkingdate !== oNewData.cust_lastworkingdate) {
                    bLwdChanged = true;
                }

                // --- Step 3: Apply validation rules ---
                const aMessages = [];

                if (oNewData.cust_rehire === "Y" && (!oNewData.cust_rehirecomments || oNewData.cust_rehirecomments.trim() === "")) {
                    aMessages.push("â€¢ Rehire comments are required when rehire flag is set to 'Yes'.");
                }

                if (bLwdChanged && (!oNewData.cust_ardcomments || oNewData.cust_ardcomments.trim() === "")) {
                    aMessages.push("â€¢ ARD comments are required when Last Working Date has been changed.");
                }

                // --- Step 4: Show error message and prevent save ---
                return new Promise(function (fnResolve, fnReject) {
                    if (aMessages.length > 0) {
                        const sMessage = "Please address the following issues before saving:\n\n" + aMessages.join("\n");
                        MessageBox.error(sMessage, {
                            actions: [MessageBox.Action.OK],
                            onClose: fnReject
                        });
                    } else {
                        fnResolve();
                    }
                });
            }
        }
    });
});

How It Works

  1. The beforeSaveExtension method is triggered automatically before the Save action on the Object Page.

  2. We first read the current draft data and the original active entity.

  3. We compare fields like cust_lastworkingdate to detect changes.

  4. Based on certain conditions (like flag = â€˜Yâ€™ ), we push validation messages into an array.

  5. If there are validation errors, a MessageBox appears with all issues listed, and the save action is prevented.

UI Screenshots

     

When both the conditions are met :
-> last working day is changed and rehire flag is set to 'Y'

-> only last working day is changed

-> only rehire flag is set to 'Y'

 

Key Takeaways

  • Always perform value-dependent validations in the beforeSaveExtension hook for extensibility.

  • Use getOriginalProperty to safely compare values between draft and active entities.

  • Consolidate all validation messages for a better user experience rather than showing multiple alerts.

entry.title: Agentic coding of an SAP mobile app with Windsurf
entry.content:
In this blog post, I am going to create a similar mobile app as Iâ€™ve previously created in SAP Build Code. However, this time I will be using the Windsurf AI-powered IDE, combined with our recently released MCP server for mobile development kit.

It is important to note that while Windsurf is featured in this example, SAP is evaluating several coding agents to ensure broad compatibility with our MCP servers. This demonstration does not imply preference or endorsement of any product or vendor.

In my previous blog post, Iâ€™ve showcased the creation of a simple list-detail app with Cursor. Some would consider this scenario a bit too simple as the user of the app can only view information, and there is no authentication involved.

For this post, weâ€™ll focus on the mobile app creation and reuse an existing CAP-based data service, which combines a basic Product entity with a Supplier entity exposed from a demo instance of S/4HANA Public Cloud edition. In this extension scenario, role-based access is implemented for authenticated users and depending on the role assigned, users can create, update and delete data.

The basic steps showcased here are:

  1. Create a new mobile app definition in SAP Mobile Services and connect it to the BTP destination of an existing data service
  2. Access your Cloud Foundry environment
  3. Open Windsurf and ...
    1. Activate MCP server for mobile development kit
    2. Configure Rules for the agent
    3. Ensure the MDK Editor extension for VS Code is installed
    4. Use the Mobile App Editor offered by the extension to retrieve relevant information from SAP Mobile Services
  4. Start the agentic coding journey.

Creating the mobile app in SAP Mobile Services

Assuming you have an instance of SAP Mobile Services available in your SAP BTP subaccount, open the Mobile Services Admin cockpit.  You can do this via Service Marketplace, select Mobile Services and open the Support link. There is no need to create an instance here.

In the Mobile Services Admin cockpit, navigate to the Mobile Applications > Native/MDK tab and click New. Select Mobile Development Kit (MDK) as the type of application. Click Next.

Provide details about the app.

Click Next and leave the remaining configuration steps unchanged. Select Finish after reviewing the selected options.

Once the app definition is created, select Connectivity and select + to create a new mobile destination. This destination will act as a bridge between the mobile app and the data service.

In this case, I will use the destination type SAP Destination Service, as I am going to use the BTP destination that was created during the deployment of my CAP service to BTP. In the dropdown list for Cloud Destination Name, Iâ€™ve picked the name of the BTP destination.

Navigating back to the mobile app entry in SAP Mobile Services, we now select Security. We edit the application settings and make sure to Enable Cross Context SSO. This feature in SAP Mobile Services allows users to reuse their OAuth tokens obtained in one context (like a desktop browser or mobile browser) in another context (like a native mobile app). This eliminates the need for users to log in again when switching between platforms. It allows for seamless user authentication across multiple backend systems. In our case, we have a CAP-based service deployed to BTP that requires authentication, that makes use of an external data source coming from an S/4HANA Cloud system.

We are now done configuring the mobile app in SAP Mobile Services.

Access your Cloud Foundry environment

To be able to exchange information between your (local) development environment and your SAP Mobile Services instance, you need to log in to your BTP environment on Cloud Foundry. Make sure you have installed the Cloud Foundry CLI.

The easiest way to log in is by using the following command and follow the instructions to open the provided URL:

cf  login <your target endpoint> --sso

Your target endpoint is visible on the Overview page of your BTP subaccount as â€œAPI Endpointâ€.

Setting up Windsurf

We'll now open the Windsurf IDE. Before getting started with agentic coding, we need to configure a few things.

Add MCP server

Open the Windsurf Settings and select open MCP Marketplace. Add and enable the MCP server for mobile development kit. More details on how to do this can be found in the Setup guide.

Define Global Rules

To provide some guidance for the agent, define the following Global Rules. You can refine these rules as needed.

## Guidelines for MDK

Donâ€™t generate .service.metadata file

Donâ€™t generate .xml file in â€˜Servicesâ€™ folder

Donâ€™t change .project.json file

Installing the MDK Extension

As Windsurf does not offer a direct way to download and install extensions from Microsoft's Visual Studio Marketplace, we will need to manually download and install the MDK Extension (VSIX). There are a few options. The easiest one is opening VS Code, search for "mdk" in the Extensions: Marketplace pane and select the "mobile development kit extension for Visual Studio Code". Click the gear icon and select Download VSIX from the dropdown menu.

Drop the downloaded VSIX file into the Windsurf workspace, right click the file and select "Install Extension VSIX".

If you have already installed the extension in VS Code, then Windsurf is able to import the extensions directly.

Note: the drawback is that you have to check and perform updates manually. We are considering publishing our extensions on Open VSX as well.

Retrieve the mobile application details from SAP Mobile Services

For this project, we need to collect information about the mobile app definition and mobile destination we've created earlier. This information will be used by our tools when generating project artifacts. In Windsurf, go to the Command Palette and open â€œMDK: Open Mobile Application Editorâ€.

The Mobile Application Editor opens. We then select the application weâ€™ve created in SAP Mobile Services and tick the box of the destination.

By clicking â€œAdd App to Projectâ€, we collect all relevant information into a file named â€œ.service.metadataâ€. This information will be used to create the mobile application project in the next steps.

In case you are presented with the following popup, youâ€™ve missed the Security configuration in SAP Mobile Services to Enable Cross Context SSO.

Start agentic coding

We can now start coding, or should I say ... prompting. In Windsurf we open Cascade and prompt:

Create a mobile app allowing users to create, update and delete Products.

After some thinking and checking various tools offered through the MCP server for mobile development kit, the agent creates an app based on the CRUD template, makes several adjustments, triggers a build,  resolves linting issues, validates and deploys the app and finally shows the QR code for onboarding. I did not expect a 'one-shot prompt' to get this far!

Curious to see the result, we scan the QR code on the mobile phone and check the result.

The result is pretty standard output as you would get from a template. The list view shows mainly ID numbers, and they are even duplicated. The detail page contains a huge amount of information that is not easily consumed on a mobile device.

Let's make some adjustments. Prompts:

On the main page, change the title to "Products and Suppliers", replace the text "ProductsAndSuppliers" to "Windsurf showcase" and change the "Products" to "Show Products list".
On the list page, change the supplier id to supplier name

Figuring out the correct way to get to the supplier name took a few iterations of coding, build and deploy.

Eventually, the result is as follows:

The list view is more useful now. However, the selection of the supplier on the detail page is also just a list of IDs. It would be better to select based on supplier names.

Prompts:

On the detail page, change the supplier id to supplier name and show less details so the information can be easily consumed on a mobile device.
Attached are screenshots of the app while navigation the pages. Make them look more professional. Consult the documentation to confirm what is possible with MDK.

 And finally, I've asked to

Add a footer bar at the bottom of the screen with the text "Powered by Mobile Development Kit.

The last prompt took several iterations to get the right result. We probably need to enhance the information/knowledge we've collected in the MCP server to optimize this.

The end result:


Conclusion

Developing a mobile app based on Mobile Development Kit has become a lot easier with coding agents that can tap into an MCP server to use tools, retrieve the latest information and best practices.

The process of developing the app was similar to what we've experienced in Cursor. As a developer, you'll have to adjust prompts and steer the agent to get the results you want. Do not expect a complete and perfect result from one single prompt.

Although we provide various tools and editors in the MDK extension, the chat (in Windsurf called Cascade) tends to become the main interface for developing the app. The tools and editors are still useful for checking the results and making minor corrections.

As always, feedback is welcome.

I am also curious the know your experiences with coding agents such as WIndsurf, in combination with our MCP server for mobile development kit.

{

                                  "User": [

                                                    "userId": "XXXXX",

entry.title: Re: Marketplace App Security in SAP: What Every Developer...
entry.content: Ensuring strong security in SAP marketplace apps begins with proper identity, tenant isolation, and data protection strategies. Common pitfalls include weak authentication, insecure APIs, and overlooked GDPR requirements. Developers should rely on SAPâ€™s native security services such as XSUAA, OAuth, and IAS for access control, while using MTX services to maintain strict tenant boundaries in multi-tenant apps. Regular vulnerability scanning, encrypted communication, and audit logging are crucial for compliance and SAP Store certification. Early alignment with SAPâ€™s Secure Development Lifecycle (SDL) and documentation standards helps avoid delays. Security must be continuous â€” from development to deployment and beyond.

entry.title: Re: Copy data from last week of last month to first week...
entry.content:
Hi @saikhancs35 ,

you can try craeting a user defined property in your date dimension to mark the lastweek of the month as 'Y and read the same in data action to copy the data to next week(which is the first week on the next month).

IF [d/Weekly].[p/lastweekofmonth] = "Y" THEN
DATA([d/Measures]="QUANTITY_WEEKLY",[d/Weekly] = NEXT(1,"WEEK",[d/Weekly])) = RESULTLOOKUP([d/Measures]= "QUANTITY_MONTHLY")
ENDIF

 Date Dimension Screesnhot with lastweekofmonth. You need to change the member management to user Managed to add a new property.

Regards,

Shivam

entry.title: Re: Required Scope Items for ISO 20022 Payment File Outpu...
entry.content:
Good day @byd 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Available Interfaces for Your Selected Scope, Integration Scenarios, Advanced Payment Management

Available Payment Medium Formats, Configuring Payment Medium Formats

To summarise, in the public cloud edition for Japan, you can generate ISO 20022 (PAIN.001) payment files without activating SAP Multi-Bank Connectivity. However, there are mandatory actions required:

  • First is to activate Bank integration file through File Interface (1EG)
  • Then configure payment medium format (e.g., /JP_ZENGINKYO or JP_PAIN_001)

It is not mandatory (but optional) to activate 4MT, J77, J78 & 16R.

This setup adheres to the clean-core approach and lets you output a fully compliant ISO 20022 file and manually upload it to your bankâ€™s web banking system

Similar question: https://community.sap.com/t5/enterprise-resource-planning-q-a/1eg-bank-integration-with-file-interface/qaq-p/12817000

https://community.sap.com/t5/financial-management-q-a/intercompany-payment-runs-through-an-international-account/qaq-p/13763191

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Outbound delivery DTR not replicated in EWM Public cloud
entry.content:
Good day @emmanuelm1 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Basic Integration with SAP Extended Warehouse Management (SAP EWM)

Integration of SAP ERP or SAP S/4HANA with Decentralized EWM in SAP S/4HANA

Direct Outbound Delivery Order , Generation of Warehouse Request of the Inbound Delivery Type

EWM delivery status handling

In summary, in public cloud, when a DTR outbound delivery is created through the wrong app and fails to replicate to EWM, it may remain stuck with the â€œIn Processâ€ status even though no warehouse request exists. There are no queues to reprocess in public cloud, and the document cannot be manually changed. I suggest your:

  • First, use Monitor Outbound Delvieries to verify that not EWM document exists.
  • Then attempt to delete or reverse the delivery in Change Outbound Delivery.

If edition is blocked, raise a ticket with SAP to reset the EWM status backend.

You can avoid this repeating itself by restricting access to apps that create stock movement outside EWM flow. Also consider training users to perform stock changes through the correct apps.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: KI-Agenten bei SAP: Ãœberblick, Beispiele, Umsetzung und Adoption mit Jochen Schneider
entry.content:
Stell Dir vor, du gibst deinem zehnjÃ¤hrigen Kind morgens die Anweisung: "In zehn Minuten fahren wir zur Schule." Was passiert? Im Idealfall zieht es sich selbststÃ¤ndig an â€“ Hose, Schuhe, Jacke â€“ und steht bereit. Genau so funktionieren KI-Agenten. Diese Metapher nutzt Jochen Schneider, verantwortlich fÃ¼r AI Capabilities auf der SAP Business Technology Platform, um zu erklÃ¤ren, was Agentic AI von herkÃ¶mmlichen Gen-AI-LÃ¶sungen unterscheidet. Im aktuellen EducationNewscast gibt er einen umfassenden Einblick in die Welt der KI-Agenten bei SAP â€“ von den Grundlagen Ã¼ber praktische Beispiele bis hin zu konkreten Tipps fÃ¼r den Einstieg.

Hier eine Zusammenfassung des fast einstÃ¼ndigen Interviews und GesprÃ¤ch - reinhÃ¶ren kÃ¶nnt ihr hier auf SAP-Podcasts - Apple - oder Spotify. Da das Thema so wichtig und spannend ist, denke ich, dass eine Zusammenfassung des Talks auch hier in der Gruppe von Interesse ist.

Was KI-Agenten wirklich ausmacht

Der Unterschied zwischen einem klassischen Chatbot oder Assistenten und einem KI-Agenten ist fundamental. WÃ¤hrend du bei ChatGPT einen Prompt eingibst und eine Antwort erhÃ¤ltst, arbeiten Agenten deutlich komplexer und autonomer. Jochen erklÃ¤rt das Prinzip anhand seiner Kinder: Du gibst nicht jeden einzelnen Schritt vor ("Zieh die Hose an, dann die Schuhe"), sondern beschreibst das gewÃ¼nschte Ergebnis. Der Agent findet dann selbst heraus, welche Schritte nÃ¶tig sind, um dieses Ziel zu erreichen.

Damit ein Agent funktioniert, braucht er drei zentrale Komponenten: Tools (die "HÃ¤nde", um Aktionen auszufÃ¼hren), Reasoning-FÃ¤higkeiten (den "Kopf", um Entscheidungen zu treffen) und Memory (das "GedÃ¤chtnis", um Kontext zu behalten und aus Erfahrungen zu lernen). Diese Kombination ermÃ¶glicht es Agenten, komplexe Aufgaben eigenstÃ¤ndig zu bewÃ¤ltigen, ohne dass du jeden Zwischenschritt vorgeben musst.

Ein wichtiger Punkt, den Jochen betont: Nicht alles sollte oder muss zum Agenten werden. Es gibt aktuell viel "Agent-Washing" â€“ Workflows, die als Agenten verkauft werden, obwohl sie deterministisch ablaufen. "Bei Agenten musst du dir immer fragen: WÃ¼rde ich diese Aufgabe so auch an mein Team geben? Wenn nicht, solltest du es auch keinem Agenten Ã¼berlassen."

"Je mehr verschiedene Informationen du in die Modelle einbringen kannst, desto besser die Prediction. Deshalb sind World Models so spannend."

Konkrete Tipps fÃ¼r die Praxis

FÃ¼r den Start:

  • Beginne mit Experimenten â€“ baue oder nutze einen Agenten, um ein GefÃ¼hl fÃ¼r die Technologie zu bekommen

  • Probiere Standard-Agenten aus, um zu sehen, was mÃ¶glich ist und wie schnell sie in deinem Unternehmen akzeptiert werden

  • Schaue dir dein Backlog an: Welche geplanten Features kÃ¶nntest du mit Agenten neu denken?

FÃ¼r die Entwicklung:

  • Nutze das Joule Studio fÃ¼r schnelle Prototypen mit Enterprise-Grade-Features

  • Denke in Outcomes, nicht in Schritten â€“ beschreibe, was erreicht werden soll, nicht wie

  • Statte Agenten mit den richtigen Tools aus, aber Ã¼berfrachte sie nicht â€“ zu viele Tools verschlechtern die QualitÃ¤t

  • WÃ¤hle das passende Modell: klein und gÃ¼nstig fÃ¼r einfache Tasks, leistungsstark fÃ¼r komplexe Reasoning-Aufgaben

FÃ¼r die Skalierung:

  • Starte mit vielen kleinen Human-in-the-Loop-Checkpoints und reduziere sie schrittweise

  • Baue technische Checks (Evals) auf, wenn menschliche Checks weniger werden

  • Implementiere Monitoring, Observability und Audit-Logs von Anfang an

  • Denke an Governance: Was passiert bei Fehlern? Wie verhinderst du Endless-Loops?

FÃ¼r die Strategie:

  • Priorisiere Use Cases nach Business Value, nicht nach technischer Coolness

  • Unterscheide klar: Workflow oder Agent? Nutze Agenten nur dort, wo FlexibilitÃ¤t und Dynamik nÃ¶tig sind

  • Bleibe adaptiv und unabhÃ¤ngig von einzelnen Modellen oder Frameworks

  • Investiere in gute Datengrundlagen â€“ die richtigen Daten zur richtigen Zeit sind entscheidend

ResÃ¼mee: Die Zukunft ist agentic â€“ aber mit AugenmaÃŸ

KI-Agenten sind keine Science-Fiction mehr, sondern RealitÃ¤t im Enterprise-Kontext. Bei SAP sind sie bereits in allen mÃ¶glichen LÃ¶sungen announced, von Finance Ã¼ber HR bis zu technischen Use Cases. Die Technologie ist beeindruckend einfach von der Bedienung aber sehr mÃ¤chtig: Agenten kÃ¶nnen komplexe Aufgaben eigenstÃ¤ndig lÃ¶sen, sich dynamisch an verÃ¤nderte Bedingungen anpassen und Prozesse augmentieren, die frÃ¼her viel manuelle Arbeit erforderten.

Aber â€“ und das ist die zentrale Botschaft von Jochen Schneider â€“ nicht alles sollte oder muss zum Agenten werden. Die Kunst liegt darin, zu erkennen, wo Agenten echten Mehrwert schaffen und wo klassische Workflows effizienter sind. Es geht nicht darum, dem Hype zu verfallen, sondern Business Value zu schaffen und Probleme zu lÃ¶sen, die heute nicht oder nicht so gut lÃ¶sbar sind.

Und was man sieht: viele Inhalte der vergangene GesprÃ¤che im Podcast von KI Ethik, humanzetrierten Design oder KI Strategie sind auch im Kontext von Agenten zentral.

Ich habe mich auf diesen Podcast mit Recherche und einem E-Learning von deeplearning.ai zu AgenticAI vorbereit. Der nÃ¤chste Schritt ist, dass ich mir eigene Agenten bastele. Mir fÃ¤llt es noch einfacher, Business Use Cases zu sehen anstatt fÃ¼r den persÃ¶nlichen Gebrauch - denn mir reichen oft GPTs oder eben das Nutzen von verschiedenen LLMs.

Oder wie seht Ihr das?

Ressourcen und weiterfÃ¼hrende Links

entry.title: Re: Standard Costing Input Parameters in SAP S/4HANA Clou...
entry.content:
Hello @byd 

Thank you for your question.

Here are some recommended references for more details.

Standard Cost Estimates, Cost Center Planning, Use of Cost Estimates with Quantity Structure,

Cost Center Activity Cost Rate Planning, Financial Products Subledger

To summarise, in public cloud, all master data and input parameters required for standard costing, which includes, BOMs, routings, yield/scarp rates, activity rates, and manufacturing versions are all supported natively. The process yield loss rate is defined at the BOM and routing levels.

Classic costing planning transactions (KP06, KP26, KSPI) are replaced by clean-core Fiori apps such as Plan Activity Rates and Calculate Activity Rates, or optionally through SAP Analytics Cloud Planning for more advanced scenarios. This step fully supports standard cost estimation, cost rollup, and variance analysis in the public cloud and therefore adhering to the clean-core extensibility model.

Let me know if you have further questions.

 

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Supply Protection and Other Methods in aATP
entry.content:
In advanced Available-to-Promise (aATP), customers have different options to optimize the availability of articles or products. Supply protection (SUP) is one of these methods, which is integrated into other processes in aATP. 
Sometimes itâ€™s not clear how supply protection works with other methods and how to differentiate to other methods. The methods have a lot in common, like the usage of a characteristics catalog. But there are also differences regarding the use cases, the usage in a process, and there are pros and cons for every method. 

Letâ€™s look at different aspects of the integration of supply protection into the following processes in aATP: 

  • Product Availability Check (PAC) 
  • Product Allocation (PAL) 
  • Backorder Processing (BOP) 
  • Alternative-Based Confirmation (ABC) 
  • Supply Assignment (aRUN) 

Link:

SAP Help: Integration into other Processes

Supply Protection and Product Availability Check (PAC) 

Planned supply protection is relevant for the product availability check (PAC), which determines whether a demand (for example, from a sales order) can be confirmed. The product availability check compares the request of the sales order with the available stock for the related material. Within this logic, there is also a check if there is supply protection available for the relevant combination of material and planning level. If yes, the system calculates the restricted quantities and reduces the available stock for the sales document. If this reduced quantity is not sufficient to meet the request, the sales document will not be (fully) confirmed for the requested delivery date. Supply protection also reduces the available stock after the replenishment lead time (RLT). However, the availability check is calculated with infinity stock. The restrictions defined by supply protection donâ€™t have an impact after the RLT.  

Whether supply protection is considered in the product availability check depends on the settings for the scope of the availability check. Only if supply protection is activated in the scope of check for the related checking rule, will PAC consider supply protection. For more information, see â€¯How to Activate Supply Protection. 

As supply protection is integrated in the basic method of the product availability check, the impact of supply protection when creating a sales document is also shown in theâ€¯Review Availability Check Resultâ€¯app, as part of the intermediate results of the check. For more information, see â€¯Supply Protection in Review Availability Check Result. 

The following illustration shows how supply protection reduces the availability by adding virtual demands:

Supply Protection within the Product Availability Check

Supply Protection and Product Allocation (PAL) 

Several use cases can be addressed with product allocation or with supply protection; and sometimes they can even be used in combination. Logically, the product allocation check is performed before the availability is checked. Therefore, PAL can limit the request which is checked in PAC (together with SUP). 

What are the differences between Product Allocation and Supply Protection? 

With the sales product allocation check, it is possible to define an upper limit for a group. A matching demand canâ€™t get a higher confirmation compared to the limit defined in product allocation. As the sales PAL is checked in advance of the product availability check, the allocation ignores the availability situation. A demand which is limited by PAC canâ€™t get more quantity, even if there is no shortage. In case of a shortage situation, a demand within the defined allocation can get the quantities if the stock is available, and if the PAL limit isnâ€™t exceeded. This leads to the issue that another requested quantity canâ€™t get confirmation although there is a matching PAL quantity. 

Supply Protection and Product Allocation
Supply protection is integrated in the product availability check and considers the availability situation. It adds virtual demands so that the availability is reduced, depending on whether the demand matches a supply protection object or not. If there is a lot of supply compared to the protected quantities, supply protection doesnâ€™t have an impact on sales. 

Can Supply Protection and Product Allocation be Used as Complementary Methods? 

Yes, with supply protection, minimum quantities can be defined. With this, it can be ensured that even in shortage situations important groups can get some quantities. With product allocation, limits can be defined, which prevent a group from taking too much quantity and not leaving enough for others. 

However, there is a risk of a wrong setup, where product allocation prevents the consumption of quantities protected by supply protection, and vice versa. This is the case when, for example, supply protection with high priority exists for a key customer, and thereâ€™s also a product allocation object matching the demands of this key customer. If the product allocation is already consumed, this customer canâ€™t order more quantity. In this case, consumption of protected quantities in supply protection isnâ€™t possible, and other demands are restricted by this. 

Advantages of Supply Protection 
Allows different settings of restrictions, but will not limit demands, if there is enough stock/supply. 

Advantages of Product Allocation 
Can be set up also on more generic levels (not only a specific material-plant combination), which requires less maintenance. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Best Practices for Supply Protection â€“ Using Supply Protection and Product Allocation 

Supply Protection and Backorder Processing (BOP) 

With backorder processing, it is possible to recheck orders with specific rules so that orders which have been confirmed may lose their confirmation while others can now get confirmed. With BOP, itâ€™s possible to reallocate available stock to competing sales orders, allowing customers to prioritize some orders ("winners") over others ("losers"). 

This seems to be close to the idea of supply protection. However, the logic of BOP is to reopen sales documents and change the sequence. A winner is processed first and has a rule to get a better result. A loser will come later and has a rule that the result can be worse. 

Links:  

SAP Help: Backorder Processing (CA-ATP-BOP) 

How does Supply Protection work together with BOP? 

While processing backorders, supply protection is checked as well. The consumption of protected quantities in supply protection will get removed temporarily, and the orders which are processed first are also checked against supply protection. The result will be different, but it considers the restrictions of supply protection. 

Naturally, it wouldnâ€™t make sense to set up protection groups with high priority for demands which should be â€œlosersâ€, according to the defined logic for BOP. 

Supply Protection and Alternative Base Confirmation (ABC) 

With ABC, it is possible to define alternative options for supply by exchanging a product and/or a plant. Depending on the rules for ABC, a demand for product A could be replaced by product B, which is not the same but treated as a good substitute. 

From the perspective of supply protection, this is always a new, independent check. The reason is quite simple: product and plant are keys for supply protection. If a product is exchanged by another product, the check for supply protection will search for matches and calculate restrictions for a different material-plant-combination. 

In this case, there wonâ€™t be a consumption for the originally matching supply protection object. For the second check, consumption might be written. 

Link: 

SAP Help: Alternative Base Confirmation (CA-ATP-ABC) 

Supply Protection and Supply Assignment (ARun) 

Supply assignment ensures that the supply is assigned to the orders according to the changing requirements. Supply protection is only a virtual demand and doesnâ€™t have a direct relationship to supply elements. Quantities which are assigned via supply assignment are not considered as available quantities in PAC. Settings in supply assignment can be used to respect or overrule restrictions defined by Supply Protection. 

Links: 

  • Community Blog: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment(ARun) 
  • SAP Help: Supply Protection in Supply Assignment 

Related Links: 

  • SAP Community Blog: Supply Protection in a Nutshell  
  • FAQ-Document: 3141787 - FAQ - Supply Protection (SUP) with advanced ATP

entry.title: Re: Job Profile URL on Latest People Profile User Card
entry.content:
Hi there, 

It is possible for an employee to view their own Job Profile. Is the example Employee - Job Classification, you use to test the Employee on Others Permission Role, the same as you use for the Employee on Self Permision Role test?  Make sure the employee who's looking at their own profile, have a Job Classification in EC, which is linked to a Job Profile (in Manage Job Profiles), and the employee on Self has the same permissions to view on Employee Profile (Employee Data fields in the permission role). 

If the answer is yes to all above questions, they should be able to see the profile. 

Best regards, 

Henriette

entry.title: Electronic Invoices in Poland (KSeF 2.0) with SAP Document and Reporting Compliance
entry.content:
Starting in February or April 2026, depending on your revenue, all Polish invoices will be required to be exchanged through KSeF. Following the postponement of the mandate originally planned for 2024, the Ministry of Finance has released a new KSeF system, KSeF 2.0 with the following timelines:

  • February 1, 2026:
    • Submission of electronic invoices to KSeF is obligatory for companies whose sales value in the previous tax year exceeded PLN 200 million.
    • Receiving e-invoices from KSeF is obligatory for all.

  • April 1, 2026 - submission of electronic invoices to KSeF is obligatory for others.

SAP has therefore updated its global solution SAP Document and Reporting Compliance to enable electronic invoices through KSeF 2.0.  To explore the latest functionalities and gain insights to accelerate your implementation, even if you have already implemented KSeF 1.0, we invite you to join our SAP hosted complimentary webinar:

Furher links and references:

  • Overview video: link 
  • Customer-facing WorkZone: link. 
  • Regulatory change manager: latest link to Regulatory Change Manager. â€™Product impactâ€™ tab has the timeline for the different systems and requirements (including upcoming ones such e-invoicing for foreign VAT Registrations, invoices visualisation in PDF with KSeF reference and QR code, validation of KSeF availability - contingency process, exclusion of B2C invoices, etc.). 
        - MoF website:https://ksef.podatki.gov.pl/

entry.title: SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model: Whatâ€™s New as of 2025-11-03?
entry.content:
Greetings  SAP Community! ğŸ‘‹ 

The SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model continues to evolve â€” and in this post, Iâ€™ll summarise the latest introduced features and improvements that further enhance efficiency, transparency, and agility in business modeling and performance analysis.

Model 
Option Field Checks for Low and High Value Entriesâ€¯ 

Weâ€™re making improvements to how the SAP Profitability and Performance Management Cloud Universal Model (SAP PaPM Cloud UM) application handles the validation of mandatory option values â€” specifically those marked as low or high. The goal is simple: make sure the system checks these values quickly and efficiently, so saving your objects takes as little time as possible.â€¯ 

With this update, validation will now be applied across all modeling functions. This means that before any object is saved, the system will automatically verify that the option field is properly filled in. If any mandatory option field is empty, the system wonâ€™t allow you to save until itâ€™s corrected. This ensures that your data stays accurate and consistent across models.â€¯ 

Figure 1: Example of a function in which Option field is not filled out

 

 

 

 

 

 


Figure 2: Sample validation message

 

 

 

 

The enhanced validation process now covers a wide range of areas, including Allocations. Model Allocations, Calculations, Model Calculations, Collections, Model Collections, Conversions (currency and unit), Model Conversions (currency and unit), Derivations, Model Derivations, Views, Model Views, Writers, Layouts, Pages, Readers, Reports, and Transfer Structure rules. In short, anywhere these option selections exist, a validation is being done to make sure everything checks out before saving.â€¯ 

Itâ€™s important to note that this update doesnâ€™t change how the validation logic works â€” it just makes it more consistent across all functions. 

Overall, this update makes the application smarter about how it handles mandatory option checks â€” keeping your data clean your saves faster, and your workflow smoother.â€¯ 

Manage Activities 
Select Reader Team When Adding a Comment 

Overviewâ€¯
A new feature has been implemented in which an Activity user can create a Comment and assign a Reader Team, this applies to creating a comment in Activity object page, comment panel in Activity Show Data, and Manage Comments. Teams within Runtime Environment and which the creator of the comment is part of, can be assigned to comment as Reader Team.â€¯â€¯ 

This ensures that the comment is visible to relevant users such as the creator, assigned Reader Team of the comment, and user with SYSTEM_ALL role/Power user. However, only the creator and user with SYSTEM_ALL role/Power user can edit and delete the created comment.â€¯ 

How does it work?â€¯ 

Reviewer POVâ€¯ 
In this scenario, the Reviewer of data in Activity or Activity user wants to create a comment for a specific Team who can only read it. Upon creating a comment, the Reader Team field is displayed that is already pre-maintained with the default Reader Team that is maintained in the Activity.â€¯ 

Upon choosing the value help of Reader Team field, available teams are displayed and can be chosen to which the Reviewer is part of and within Runtime Environment.â€¯ This behaviour applies as well when creating comments in Manage Comments.â€¯ 

 

The Reviewer created the comments separately for Activity users that are part of Comment Reader 01 and Comment Writer 01 Team and Comment Reader 02 and Comment Writer 02 Team.â€¯ 

 

Comment Reader 01 and Comment Writer 01 POVâ€¯ 
As an Activity user part of Comment Reader 01 and Comment Writer 01 Team, they can only see the comments assigned to their Team. This behaviour applies as well when checking in Manage Comments.â€¯ 

 

Comment Reader 02 and Comment Writer 02 POVâ€¯ 
As an Activity user part of Comment Reader 02 and Comment Writer 02 Team, they can only see the comments assigned to their Team. This behaviour applies as well when checking in Manage Comments.â€¯ 

 

Who can Edit or Delete created Comments?â€¯â€¯ 
As an Activity user that is part of the Comment Reader and Writer Teams, they should not be able to edit and delete the comment which they are assigned to as they are the receiver of the comments. This behaviour applies as well when attempting to edit or delete the comment in Manage Comments.â€¯ 

 

As the Reviewer/Creator of the comment and user with SYSTEM_ALL role, they can edit and delete the comment. This behaviour applies as well when attempting to edit or delete the comment in Manage Comments.â€¯ 


 

For more information, see Application Help for Universal Model â€“ Manage Activities 

Reports 
Enhanced Filtering Behaviour in Show Screen, Show Elements and Reports 

We have improved how filters work in the Show Screen/Show Elements. Now, each field can be used in only one type of filter â€” either a Story Filter or a Page Filter. To use both filters, pick one field for the Story Filter and a different one for the Page Filter. This helps you narrow down the data you see.â€¯ 

Also, in Reports, an asterisk (*) now appears on the Apply Filters button when you change any filters but havenâ€™t applied them yet. This visual indicator reminds you that your changes are not saved. To apply them, choose Apply Filters.â€¯ 

 


Email Notifications 
Simplified User Email Retrieval for Notifications 

This update enhances the mechanism for retrieving user email addresses, simplifying configuration and reducing dependency on additional services.â€¯ Previously, user email addresses were retrieved using the XSUAA-based mechanism, and the email destination had to be configured in SAP BTP.â€¯ 

With this enhancement, user email addresses are now retrieved directly from the user data within the system, so additional XSUAA configuration or BTP mail destination setup is no longer required for new configurations. 

Notes:â€¯ 
Impact on Existing Setupsâ€¯ 
For existing customers who have already configured notifications, no change or update is required.â€¯ All existing setups will continue to work as expected.â€¯ 

For Customers with Specific Security or Compliance Requirementsâ€¯ 
Certain customers may still prefer to maintain user email addresses manually for compliance purposes.â€¯ 
Such users can continue to follow the standard configuration steps provided in the documentation below. 
 
For more information, see Administration Guide for Universal Model â€“ Email Notification Setup 


Thanks for reading! 

We hope you enjoy exploring the latest improvements in the SAP PaPM Cloud Universal Model. Stay tuned for more â€œWhatâ€™s Newâ€ updates â€” and check out the PaPMCloudUMWhatsNew tag for past posts.

entry.title: Re: Add screen text field dynamically
entry.content:
Hi Geoff, you can try also the following way:

  • create a dynpro screen with a custom control
  • instantiate custom control object of class CL_GUI_CUSTOM_CONTAINER (for example in PBO)
  • (optionally) create a splitter object (class CL_GUI_SPLITTER_CONTAINER) if you need several containers for your objects
  • create dynamically your screen objects in the corresponding containers. In your case it could be class CL_GUI_INPUT_FIELD. You can find further suitable classes as subclasses of CL_GUI_CONTROL.

Last time I checked this approach, it had several limitations and was not really convenient for my solution, although it could be suitable for some of your use cases.

entry.title: How to deal with 200 responsibility groups limitation in Onboarding General Settings
entry.content:
Hi, 

We have a limitation in the creation of Responsible Groups; we need to create 527 groups to distribute the Final Review task.

First, we are creating a lookup table, but in order to associate employees with the final review task, we would need to create the table based on ONB2ResponsibilityConfig and assign those groups to each value in the table. Therefore, the table is not really useful, because we are doing the same work we still need to create 527 groups to assign them to each table entry so that the system knows which employees to assign to the tasks.

On the other hand, we performed a test, and if I include more than 200 people in a group, the task is only assigned to the first 200.

However, I donâ€™t understand the limitation Iâ€™m facing the problem is that when I try to assign a dynamic group to a responsible group, it doesnâ€™t appear even though it has been created.

Thanks in advance. Daniel

entry.title: WFA on HANA missing Fact Tables
entry.content:
When going into the Data Factory to do a configuration analysis, there are no Fact Tables available.

WFA implementation was done 2 years ago and WFA is up and running in PROD, however, no Fact Tables are available even though they were configured.

Therefore, no maintenance can be done since the configuration is not available.

The Validator also brings this forth, but we are unaware of what caused this.

All of the Metrics are available in WFA.

There are no config back-ups available.
Is there any way to bring back the configuration so we can perform maintenance and updates?

@YSE-1 @Keegan

entry.title: Re: Mobile number based [without email] registration and login to SuccessFactors Onboarding
entry.content: Thatâ€™s an interesting use case, Amol â€” Iâ€™ve seen a few clients asking for the same mobile-only onboarding flow. We havenâ€™t done it directly through IAS yet, but a workaround that helped was integrating Phonexaâ€™s SMS automation layer to handle secure URL + credential delivery. It reduces manual admin work while keeping everything logged and traceable. Still hoping SAP expands CDC-style mobile login support for ONB soon â€” itâ€™s definitely a growing need.
